item.title: Tentative Deal to Avoid Rail Strike Is Reached, Biden Announces
item.description: President Biden announced the agreement after negotiations brokered by the labor secretary lasted deep into the night.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Charles Rex Arbogast/Associated Press
item.media:description: An Amtrak passenger train heading south out of Chicago on Wednesday evening.

item.title: New Inflation Developments Are Rattling Markets and Economists. Here’s Why.
item.description: Inflation is less about pandemic and war surprises and more about economic momentum. That could make the solution more painful.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: The combination of more jobs and better pay is helping to shore up household finances, allowing families to keep spending.

item.title: In Russian Border City of Belgorod, the Ukraine War Feels Real
item.description: In Belgorod, 25 miles from Ukraine, recent losses by Russia’s military have brought home the reality of the war in a way not present elsewhere in the country.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Valerie Hopkins/The New York Times
item.media:description: In Belgorod, Russia, military vehicles marked with the letters Z, V and O, which have become symbols of the Russian invasion, ride through the city.

item.title: The Search for Intelligent Life Is About to Get a Lot More Interesting
item.description: There are an estimated 100 billion galaxies in the universe, home to an unimaginable abundance of planets. And now there are new ways to spot signs of life on them.
item.dc:creator: Jon Gertner

item.title: NY Attorney General May Sue Trump After Rejecting Settlement Offer
item.description: The attorney general, Letitia James, is also considering suing at least one of the former president’s adult children as part of her Trump Organization inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump’s family business could face stiff financial and operational penalties after a trial.

item.title: Trump Media’s Merger Delay Puts $1 Billion Financing Deal in Doubt
item.description: An agreement with hedge funds and other wealthy investors is set to expire soon, and they could walk away from the upstart social media company if conditions are not met.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump at a rally this month. His upstart social media platform, Truth Social, markets itself as an uncensored platform.

item.title: Fetterman Says Stroke Problems Have Not Slowed Down a ‘Normal’ Campaign
item.description: In one of his most extensive interviews since having a stroke, John Fetterman said he was fully capable of handling a campaign that may decide who controls the U.S. Senate.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck, Blake Hounshell and Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, a Democrat running for Senate in Pennsylvania, at a rally in Blue Bell on Sunday. He acknowledges lingering problems with his speech since a stroke in May.

item.title: Congress Told Colleges to Return Native Remains. What’s Taking So Long?
item.description: The University of North Dakota, the latest U.S. college to acknowledge keeping Indigenous bones and artifacts, pledged to work with tribal leaders on returning them.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Jaida Grey Eagle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of North Dakota campus in Grand Forks, where the remains of Native American people have been found.

item.title: Thousands Join ‘The Queue’ to See Queen Elizabeth Lying in State
item.description: Thousands of people waited in line — a very long line — to pay homage at the coffin of Queen Elizabeth II, who will lie in state until her funeral on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line to see Queen Elizabeth II lying in state in London crossed the River Thames and snaked for miles along the South Bank.

item.title: Florida Flies 2 Planeloads of Migrants to Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: The moneyed summer resort became an unlikely arena in the fight over illegal immigration. Republican states have bused thousands of migrants to New York and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Remy Tumin and Eliza Fawcett
item.media:credit: Ray Ewing/The Vineyard Gazette
item.media:description: Migrants and local officials at St. Andrew’s Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard, on Wednesday.

item.title: Adams Wants to Reassess a Shelter System ‘Nearing Its Breaking Point’
item.description: New York City’s homeless system is built around the city’s unique right to shelter. On Wednesday, Mayor Eric Adams said the system should be reconsidered.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since May, 11,000 migrants have entered the city’s shelter system.

item.title: The New Covid Boosters Are Amazing News
item.description: These updated vaccines are more protective, could fight future variants and help stave off long Covid.
item.dc:creator: Zeynep Tufekci
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: The Space Between Brain Death and Organ Donation
item.description: An I.C.U. doctor offers a better understanding of brain death.
item.dc:creator: Daniela J. Lamas
item.media:credit: Emiliano Ponzi

item.title: Britain 3, America 0
item.description: A third woman is now leading Britain. The U.S. has had, um, ....
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: The Transcendent Power of Walking
item.description: Walking in my neighborhood taught me what running wild in the mountains couldn’t.
item.dc:creator: Francis Sanzaro
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Population Growth Has Nearly Flatlined. Is That So Bad?
item.description: Countries around the world are confronting the costs — and potential benefits — of an aging population.
item.dc:creator: Spencer Bokat-Lindell
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by Ed Jones and Issouf Sanogo, via Getty Images

item.title: Lindsey Graham’s Unbelievably Cruel Abortion Ban
item.description: Either he doesn’t know how pregnancy works, or he doesn’t care.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: What School Anxiety Dreams Teach Us About Ourselves
item.description: Why we keep having school anxiety dreams, and what they may mean.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Eleanor Davis

item.title: Apostle of Black Power
item.description: I’ve urged Black people to reverse the Great Migration and move to the South. Who’s with me?
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.category: The Devil You Know: A Black Power Manifesto (Book)
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Magana/Associated Press

item.title: The Fog of San Francisco
item.description: It’s a life force, with an uncertain future.
item.dc:creator: John Branch
item.media:credit: Nina Riggio for The New York Times

item.title: Could a National Abortion Ban Save Republicans?
item.description: An effort by Senator Lindsey Graham to mend a rift in his party seems to have backfired.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Luke Vander Ploeg, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Patricia Willens, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham, right, His proposal for an abortion ban includes exceptions for rape, incest and the life or physical health of the mother.

item.title: Strong Women, Madwomen, Mob Women
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Queen Elizabeth, and the Power and Limitations of Inspiring Women
item.description: Changing minds can be powerful, but history shows that changing societies takes more.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Piccadilly Circus in central London on Thursday.

item.title: Solar Energy Is Helping Schools Make Ends Meet
item.description: Public schools are increasingly using savings from solar energy to upgrade facilities, help their communities, and give teachers raises — often with no cost to taxpayers.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times

item.title: Giorgia Meloni May Lead Italy, and Europe Is Worried
item.description: The hard-right leader has excoriated the European Union in the past, and she regularly blasts illegal immigrants and George Soros. But she is closer than ever to becoming prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni, center, who would be the first woman to lead Italy, posed for a photograph with a supporter in Cagliari, Sardinia, this month.

item.title: Ethereum’s Long-Awaited ‘Merge’ Reaches the Finish Line
item.description: Ethereum, the most popular cryptocurrency platform, completed its much-anticipated switch to a more energy-efficient infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: The original system for mining cryptocurrency, known as proof of work, uses vast amounts of energy.

item.title: The Hollywood Merger That Could Reshape Soccer’s Transfer Market
item.description: As two behemoths join forces against boutique agencies in the fight for control and commissions, some fear profits could come before players.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: The merger this year of Creative Artists Agency and ICM Partners created a soccer juggernaut.

item.title: What Is Brain Fog and How Can I Treat It?
item.description: Researchers are just beginning to understand the cognitive dysfunction that some people experience with Covid-19 and a range of other health issues.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Processed Meat and Health Risks: What to Know
item.description: Here’s what the experts say.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Should You Put on Sunscreen or Foundation First?
item.description: There’s good news and bad news when it comes to sun protection and cosmetics.
item.dc:creator: Caira Blackwell
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Is Driving High as Dangerous as Driving Drunk?
item.description: There’s limited data on how marijuana impacts driving performance, but experts urge caution before getting behind the wheel.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Take on an Empty Stomach.’ How Do You Know When Your Stomach Is Empty?
item.description: Two hours after eating is a crude rule of thumb. A more accurate answer depends on the drugs you are taking and your medical conditions.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.
item.media:credit: Stuart Bradford

item.title: F.D.R. and Andy Warhol All Came for Art. Now the Movers Have Arrived.
item.description: How do you relocate more than 100 years of (haphazardly organized) fine art, maps and prints? The family that’s owned the Old Print Shop is finding out right now.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Farrell and Mary Inhea Kang
item.media:description: Harry and Robert Newman in the shop their family has occupied for more than 100 years.
